@EthioHRC categorically condemns killings, & displacement of civilians, & urges regional authorities to carry out impartial, prompt, effective investigations into circumstances that led to killings. Read our statement on Benishangul-Gumuz below (4/4) https://t.co/8fgzgXfygR
An official source on the ground has informed @EthioHRC that there have been at least two rounds of killings of civilians, and hundreds of civilians have also been displaced. (3/4)

@EthioHRC has received disturbing reports from Benishangul-Gumuzâ€™s Metekel Zone, Bulen Woreda, Apar Kebele, and Wonbera Woreda, Melkan Kebele. The regional govt has confirmed that at least two instances of violence occurred on 6 Sept 2020 and between 7 â€“ 13 Sept 2020.Â (2/4)

The Ethiopian Human Rights Commission (@EthioHRC) is deeply concerned by security events unfolding in Benishangul-Gumuz Region. Our statement on killings and displacement in the region (Thread 1/4) https://t.co/idkn7bnGRr

Do human rights abuses in Oromia amount to genocide? 

Chief Commissioner @DanielBekele urges caution over labels, but says @EthioHRC will soon share findings of its probe that determined the nature & magnitude of abuses.

Please read @EthioHRCâ€™s full statement on urgent needs & recommendations here (9): https://t.co/7PjqMVVl46
Police should expedite their investigation and release those wrongly arrested & those entitled to bail. (8)

3rd: Large number of arrests & conditions of detention.Â 
Many prisons in Oromia are overcrowded, risking Covid-19 infection. Food, hygiene/sanitation remain inadequate. Some detainees alleged beatings & inhumane treatment. (7)
In Agarfa & Shashemene, local officials threatened to withhold assistance unless victims returned home. (6)

2nd: Delivery of humanitarian assistance.
Displaced victims in Agarfa, Asasa, Dodola, Shashemene, & others took shelter in churches & other temporary shelters with limited food & supplies. (5)

Victims in Dodola cited July 16 circulation of list with 60 names who were warned to leave town or face reprisals. In Shashemene, unknown individuals went house to house demanding 5,000 to 10,000 birr or face death, property destruction. (4)
Calm has returned in several areas, but the risk of death, injury, & property destruction exists. Displaced victims are still being threatened. (3)

Upcoming full report will reflect findings & recommendations. Ahead of the full report, @EthioHRC outlines 3 areas with urgent needs. 1st: Security protection for communities who remain vulnerable to further violence. (2)

Abuses in Oromia: @EthioHRC launched a probe into human rights violations committed in the wake of Hachalu Hundessaâ€™s death. The commission spent two weeks in over 40 areas, gathering accounts from victims, witnesses, the govt, & hospitals. (Thread 1/9)

(THREAD 2/2) The death toll since the outbreak of violence on August 10 has risen to 17, incl children, after one more person died on Wednesday. Three people remain in critical condition in Sodo. @EthioHRC reiterates its call for security forces to exercise maximum restraint.
(THREAD 1/2) Ethiopian Human Rights Commission (@EthioHRC) reiterates its deep concern over persistent violence and use of excessive force against protesters by security forces in Wolaita Zone

â€œSecurity forces should exercise maximum restraint from using lethal force in dealing with peaceful protest. Such actions only exacerbate an already tense situation.â€

â€œAlthough the Directive allows the Ministry of Transport to issue permits, in exceptional cases, the fact that it came into effect without advance notice and the administrative challenges that may arise in issuing permits could lead to unnecessary disruption.â€ @DanielBekele

â€œconsidering that there are people who move around using their private vehicles for essential and humanitarian services â€¦the restriction should be reconsidered as it can put additional strain on public transport and thus have a negative impactâ€ @DanielBekele

â€œThe necessity and proportionality of the restriction imposed by the Ministerial Committee on the use of private vehicles should also be reconsidered from the perspective of the overall objective of the state of emergencyâ€ said @DanielBekele @EthioHRC

The Principle of Legality dictates that all emergency measures and restrictions be adequately and publicly announced and provide an advance notice on compliance period for enforcement in accordance with the law.
Emergency measures imposed by the Federal and regional governments are permissible only where they are strictly necessary and proportional in view of the exigencies of the situation.

It is to be recalled that restrictions on public transport previously imposed without advance notice by the Amhara and Southern regional governments have resulted in lots of confusion and unnecessary distress.

Although the emergency restriction includes measures necessary to ensure social distancing and reduce overall movement aimed at preventing the spread of #COVID19, the absence of advance notice, as well as the necessity and proportionality of some of the measures raises concern.

The Transport Directive issued by the Ministerial Committee on 17 April 2020 which imposed various restrictions on private vehicles and public transport services effective from the day the Directive was issued should have given sufficient advance notice.

â€œAny restriction imposed by Federal and regional governments on freedom of movement and public transport services to prevent the spread of #COVID19 should take into account human rights principlesâ€, said @EthioHRC

The functioning of an independent and impartial judiciary cannot be suspended or delegated even during a state of emergency. Without prejudice to the necessary administrative adjustments, the administration of justice by the judiciary must continue unhindered.

Law enforcement agencies play critical role to ensure that the state of emergency, which is the first for Ethiopiaâ€™s new political chapter, is implemented in a manner that is consistent with the Constitution and international human rights obligations.
The Government shall not restrict or suspend fundamental human rights which are  non-derogable under the Constitution and international human rights law.

The Government should take the necessary preventative measures to ensure that the state of emergency does not exacerbate the vulnerability of groups at risk of human rights abuse such as women, children, people with disabilities and displaced persons.

Limitations on the enjoyment of human rights or any other measure taken in a state of emergency shall not involve discrimination on the ground of race, religion, sex, language or any other similar legally protected characteristics.

The independence of the judiciary and the right to effective judicial remedies shall be maintained in order to ensure that emergency measures do not exceed the limits imposed by the state of emergency law, and further ensure the full protection of non-derogable rights.

The special powers given to the Government in exceptional emergency situations must be exercised only within the limits provided under the law and applied in conformity with  constitutional and international obligations.

.@EthioHRC reminds law enforcement agencies to be guided by human rights and constitutional norms, respect and protect non-derogable rights, and discharge their functions in accountable and professional manner while implementing the State of Emergency Proclamation and Regulation.

.@EthioHRC recognizes the need for the measures adopted by the Federal and State governments to prevent and control the spread of COVID-19, including the proclamation of national state of emergency by the Federal government.
